body:
The OutOfMemoryError message is the important one, you've run out of memory.
Can you edit zap.sh and change the line:
`JMEM="-Xmx512m"` to `JMEM="-Xmx1024m"`and try again?
You can change this via the ZAP UI, but thats not much use in daemon mode ;)
In the next version of ZAP you'll be able to change this via a command line switch.

@psiinon I tried it and now the error is

> AWT blocker activation interrupted:
> java.lang.InterruptedException
>     at java.lang.Object.wait(Native Method)
>     at java.lang.Object.wait(Object.java:503)
>     at sun.awt.AWTAutoShutdown.activateBlockerThread(AWTAutoShutdown.java:349)
>     at sun.awt.AWTAutoShutdown.notifyThreadBusy(AWTAutoShutdown.java:174)
>     at java.awt.EventQueue$5.run(EventQueue.java:1058)
>     at java.awt.EventQueue$5.run(EventQueue.java:1049)
>     at java.security.AccessController.doPrivileged(Native Method)
>     at java.awt.EventQueue.initDispatchThread(EventQueue.java:1048)
>     at java.awt.EventQueue.postEventPrivate(EventQueue.java:282)
>     at java.awt.EventQueue.postEvent(EventQueue.java:257)
>     at java.awt.EventQueue.invokeLater(EventQueue.java:1233)
>     at org.zaproxy.zap.extension.alert.ExtensionAlert.siteNodeChanged(Unknown Source)
>     at org.zaproxy.zap.extension.alert.ExtensionAlert.alertFound(Unknown Source)
>     at org.zaproxy.zap.extension.pscan.PassiveScanThread.raiseAlert(Unknown Source)
>     at org.zaproxy.zap.extension.pscanrules.HeaderXssProtectionScanner.raiseAlert(HeaderXssProtectionScanner.java:90)
>     at org.zaproxy.zap.extension.pscanrules.HeaderXssProtectionScanner.scanHttpResponseReceive(HeaderXssProtectionScanner.java:71)

Seems that memory issue is related to the fact that ZAP creates a huge number of connections

`netstat -uta | grep 8090 | wc -l`
`16640`
Are there any estimate when this issue has a chance to be fixed?

Well, we dont actually know what the issue is yet.
Does the last error actually cause any problems? It could be irrelevant.
The problem is that I can't run ZAP on EC2 instance running linux, so I believe it can be a blocker for many people. As @thc202 mentioned, ZAP is entering a request loop and runs out of memory.

FYI, I'm already working on a fix.
(I still need need to set up a test env to verify the fix, though.)
Thanks @thc202, let me know if you need any additional information or help with reproducing it.

issue.title: Fix (non-local IP address) ZAP API loop

repository.name: zaproxy
repository.description: The ZAP by Checkmarx Core project

issue.body:
Check if the requested address belongs to any of the network interfaces
when checking if it is recursive, that is, a request to ZAP itself,
preventing a request loop when the IP address is non-local.

Add the check to method ProxyThread.isRecursive(HttpRequestHeader) and
refactor, to reduce code complexity, by extracting simpler methods.

Fix #2318 - ZAP Error [java.net.SocketTimeoutException]: Read timed out
when running on AWS EC2 instance

body: @psiinon hey, was this fix included in the weekly docker image? I've just pulled owasp/zap2docker-weekly, ran `docker run -p 8090:8090 -i owasp/zap2docker-weekly zap.sh -daemon -port 8090 -host 0.0.0.0` and got the same error.
Yeah, it _should_. Are you still using a public IP address to access ZAP?

@thc202 yes, I use public IP address assigned to AWS instance. The only change I noticed that netstat shows just 1 connection now, not dozen
`netstat -uta | grep 8090 | wc -l`
`1`

but in browser I get an error:

> ZAP Error [java.net.SocketTimeoutException]: Read timed out

Stack Trace:
java.net.SocketTimeoutException: Read timed out

    at org.apache.commons.httpclient.HttpMethodBase.execute(HttpMethodBase.java:1147)
    at org.apache.commons.httpclient.HttpMethodDirector.executeWithRetry(HttpMethodDirector.java:450)
    at org.apache.commons.httpclient.HttpMethodDirector.executeMethod(HttpMethodDirector.java:191)
    at org.apache.commons.httpclient.HttpClient.executeMethod(HttpClient.java:397)
